choices.text: Chorda tympani arises from the tympanic segment and supplies the parotid gland
Nerve to stapedius arises at the level of the second genu and supplies the stapedius muscle
Greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the mastoid segment and supplies the submandibular gland
Cervical branch of the facial nerve carries taste sensation from posterior one-third of the tongue

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the branches of the facial nerve is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nerve to stapedius arises at the level of the second genu and supplies the stapedius muscle

 

  • The nerve to stapedius emerges at the second genu of the facial nerve, innervating the stapedius muscle within the middle ear.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Chorda tympani arises from the tympanic segment and supplies the parotid gland: Incorrect. Chorda tympani arises from the vertical (mastoid) segment and supplies the submandibular and sublingual glands, not the parotid. Taste fibers from anterior two-thirds of the tongue also run in it.

 

Option C. Greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the mastoid segment and supplies the submandibular gland: Incorrect. It arises from the geniculate ganglion (not mastoid segment) and supplies the lacrimal, nasal, and palatal glands, not the submandibular.

 

Option D. Cervical branch of the facial nerve carries taste sensation from posterior one-third of the tongue: Incorrect. Taste from posterior one-third is via glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the facial nerve. Cervical branch of facial nerve supplies platysma (muscle of facial expression).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nerve to stapedius arises at the second genu of the facial nerve and supplies the stapedius muscle in the middle ear.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 94–95.

choices.text: The facial nerve lies lateral to the cartilaginous pointer of the external auditory canal
The facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of digastric and the styloid process
The facial nerve lies deep and posterior to the tympanomastoid suture
The facial nerve passes medially to the styloid process during its extracranial course

questions.text: Which of the following statements about surgical landmarks for locating the facial nerve during parotid surgery is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of digastric and the styloid process

 

  • When tracing the posterior belly of digastric to its attachment at the digastric groove, the facial nerve is found between it and the styloid process, making this a useful landmark during parotid dissection.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The facial nerve lies lateral to the cartilaginous pointer of the external auditory canal: Incorrect. The cartilaginous pointer (tragal pointer) "points" to the facial nerve, which lies 1 cm deep and slightly anterior and inferior to it — not lateral.

 

Option C. The facial nerve lies deep and posterior to the tympanomastoid suture: Incorrect. The nerve lies 6–8 mm deep to the tympanomastoid suture, but not posterior to it.

 

Option D. The facial nerve passes medially to the styloid process during its extracranial course: Incorrect. The nerve passes lateral to the styloid process after exiting the stylomastoid foramen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During parotid surgery, the facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of the digastric muscle and the styloid process, serving as a reliable surgical landmark.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.

choices.text: Electrogustometry showing reduced taste sensation on the anterior tongue
Absence of stapedial reflex detected by tympanometry
Schirmer test showing decreased lacrimation on the affected side
Reduced salivation from the parotid gland

questions.text: Which of the following topodiagnostic tests is used to identify a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion in a case of lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schirmer test showing decreased lacrimation on the affected side

 

  • The greater superficial petrosal nerve, which carries secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland, branches off at the geniculate ganglion. So, reduced lacrimation indicates a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

 

 

(A) Suprageniculate (transgeniculate) lesions

 

Interrupt secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland at or proximal to the geniculate ganglion, leading to decreased lacrimation.

 

(B) Suprastapedial lesions

 

Disrupt fibers proximal to the stapedius branch, causing loss of both the stapedial reflex and taste, while sparing lacrimation.

 

(C) Infrastapedial lesions

 

Affect the chorda tympani but spare the stapedius branch, resulting in impaired taste sensation with preserved stapedial reflex and normal lacrimation.

 

(D) Infrachordal lesions

 

Involve only the motor fibers distal to the chorda tympani, producing isolated facial weakness without affecting taste, lacrimation, or the stapedial reflex.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Electrogustometry showing reduced taste sensation on the anterior tongue: Incorrect. This test evaluates the chorda tympani, so taste loss implies a lesion above the chorda tympani, but below the geniculate ganglion if lacrimation is unaffected.

 

Option B. Absence of stapedial reflex detected by tympanometry: Incorrect. Loss of the stapedial reflex suggests a lesion above the nerve to stapedius, which is distal to the geniculate ganglion.

 

Option D. Reduced salivation from the parotid gland: Incorrect. The parotid gland is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the facial nerve. The facial nerve (via chorda tympani) affects the submandibular and sublingual glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased lacrimation on Schirmer test suggests a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion, where secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland originate.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 102.

choices.text: The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound
The amplifier picks up sound and sends it directly to the tympanic membrane
The receiver captures sound and converts it into electrical signals for processing
The microphone sends electrical signals directly to the cochlea through a bone conduction pathway

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of components in a conventional hearing aid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound

 

  • This is the basic working principle of a conventional hearing aid:
    • The microphone picks up environmental sound and converts it into an electrical signal.
    • The amplifier boosts this signal to a suitable level.
    • The receiver then converts the amplified electrical signal back into sound, which is delivered to the ear.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The amplifier picks up sound and sends it directly to the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. The microphone, not the amplifier, picks up sound. The amplifier deals with electrical impulses, not sound waves.

 

Option C. The receiver captures sound and converts it into electrical signals for processing: Incorrect. This is the role of the microphone, not the receiver. The receiver works at the final stage to deliver the processed sound.

 

Option D. The microphone sends electrical signals directly to the cochlea through abone conduction pathway: Incorrect. This describes bone conduction hearing aids, not conventional air-conduction hearing aids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a conventional hearing aid, the microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier boosts them, and the receiver converts them back to sound delivered to the ear.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

choices.text: Chronic ear discharge not amenable to medical or surgical treatment
Mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with intact external ear canal
Intermittent tinnitus with normal hearing thresholds
Conductive hearing loss in a patient who prefers cosmetic hearing aid solutions

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct indication for Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) placement?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic ear discharge not amenable to medical or surgical treatment

 

  • This is one of the key indications for BAHA use. Patients with chronic otorrhea cannot tolerate air-conduction hearing aids due to moisture and infection. BAHA bypasses the external and middle ear, making it ideal in such cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with intact external ear canal: Incorrect. These patients are typically managed with conventional air-conduction hearing aids, not BAHA.

 

Option C. Intermittent tinnitus with normal hearing thresholds: Incorrect. Tinnitus without hearing loss is not an indication for BAHA. Treatment involves counseling, sound therapy, or other medical options.

 

Option D. Conductive hearing loss in a patient who prefers cosmetic hearing aid solutions: Incorrect. Cosmetic preference alone is not a justification for BAHA. It is indicated when air-conduction aids are contraindicated or not tolerated (e.g., canal atresia, persistent discharge).

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAHA is indicated in patients with chronic ear discharge, canal atresia, or single-sided deafness when conventional air-conduction hearing aids are not feasible.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123

choices.text: Longer duration of deafness with no prior use of hearing aids
Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children
Prelingual adults with no auditory experience before implantation
Use of single-channel implants with auditory training

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with better clinical outcomes following cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children

 

  • Younger age, especially around 12 months, correlates with better auditory and speech development due to greater neural plasticity. Early stimulation improves language acquisition and long-term outcomes.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Longer duration of deafness with no prior use of hearing aids: Incorrect. Longer auditory deprivation and lack of prior auditory stimulation are associated with poorer outcomes, especially in prelingual adults.

 

Option C. Prelingual adults with no auditory experience before implantation: Incorrect. These individuals derive limited benefit, mostly sound awareness, with little improvement in speech comprehension or language development.

 

Option D. Use of single-channel implants with auditory training: Incorrect. Multichannel implants are now standard and perform significantly better than single-channel devices. Single-channel devices are obsolete.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Younger age at implantation, particularly in prelingually deaf children, is a strong predictor of successful outcomes with cochlear implants due to higher neural plasticity.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

choices.text: Subjective tinnitus is heard by both the patient and the examiner
Objective tinnitus is always associated with sensorineural hearing loss
Objective tinnitus can be heard by the examiner, often using a stethoscope
Subjective tinnitus indicates a middle ear pathology that generates audible sounds

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the types of tinnitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Objective tinnitus can be heard by the examiner, often using a stethoscope

 

  • Objective tinnitus results from actual physical sounds (like turbulent blood flow or muscle contractions) that can sometimes be audible externally using a stethoscope.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Subjective tinnitus is heard by both the patient and the examiner
Incorrect. Subjective tinnitus is heard only by the patient, with no external sound: detectable.

 

Option B. Objective tinnitus is always associated with sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. Objective tinnitus is often due to vascular, muscular, or mechanical causes, not typically associated with sensorineural loss.

 

Option D. Subjective tinnitus indicates a middle ear pathology that generates audible sounds: Incorrect. Subjective tinnitus does not involve actual sound generation. It's a perceived sound without a physical source and may be associated with inner ear or neurological causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinnitus is classified as subjective (heard only by the patient) or objective (can also be heard by the examiner using a stethoscope).

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

choices.text: Bell palsy most commonly affects young males and is often associated with trigeminal neuralgia
The most common cause of Bell palsy is trauma to the facial nerve during mastoid surgery
Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, peripheral facial paralysis with viral and ischemic etiologies being most common
Surgical decompression of the facial nerve is the first-line treatment in all patients with Bell palsy

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bell palsy is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, peripheral facial paralysis with viral and ischemic etiologies being most common

 

  • Bell palsy is characterized by sudden-onset, idiopathic lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Proposed causes include herpes simplex virus, vascular ischemia, hereditary predisposition, and autoimmunity.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bell palsy most commonly affects young males and is often associated with trigeminal neuralgia: Incorrect. Bell palsy affects both sexes equally, and although it can occur at any age, incidence increases with age. It is not associated with trigeminal neuralgia, which involves a different cranial nerve (CN V).

 

Option B. The most common cause of Bell palsy is trauma to the facial nerve during mastoid surgery: Incorrect. Bell palsy is idiopathic in nature and accounts for 60–75% of facial paralysis cases. Facial nerve trauma is a known cause of facial paralysis, but not of Bell palsy specifically.

 

Option D. Surgical decompression of the facial nerve is the first-line treatment in all patients with Bell palsy: Incorrect. Surgical decompression is reserved for select cases. First-line treatment includes reassurance, steroid therapy, and eye care. Most cases recover spontaneously or with medical management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, lower motor neuron facial paralysis commonly caused by viral infections and vascular ischemia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 97–100.

choices.text: Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation)
Exposure keratitis due to loss of tear film
Synkinesis caused by cross motor innervation
Frey’s syndrome resulting from parotid surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of peripheral facial paralysis due to faulty regeneration of parasympathetic fibers?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation)

 

  • This refers to unilateral lacrimation during eating, caused by misdirected regeneration of parasympathetic fibers that mistakenly supply the lacrimal gland instead of salivary glands. Treatment may involve sectioning the greater superficial petrosal nerve or tympanic neurectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Exposure keratitis due to loss of tear film: Incorrect. This results from incomplete eye closure, leading to dryness and corneal damage, but it is not due to nerve misdirection. It's a mechanical complication of facial paralysis.

 

Option C. Synkinesis caused by cross motor innervation: Incorrect. While also a complication, synkinesis involves involuntary simultaneous movement, not parasympathetic misrouting.

 

Option D. Frey’s syndrome resulting from parotid surgery: Incorrect. Frey’s syndrome causes sweating and flushing over the parotid region during eating due to aberrant regeneration, but it follows parotid surgery, not facial nerve injury specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation) occur due to faulty regeneration of parasympathetic fibers following facial nerve injury, causing lacrimation during eating.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103.

choices.text: ABI stimulates the cochlear nerve directly through an electrode placed in the cochlea
ABI is indicated in patients with unilateral vestibular schwannoma and normal hearing on the opposite side
ABI is placed over the cochlear nucleus complex in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle
ABI provides better speech recognition outcomes than multichannel cochlear implants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABI is placed over the cochlear nucleus complex in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle

 

  • The multielectrode array of ABI is placed on the cochlear nucleus complex within the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, allowing direct brainstem stimulation.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. ABI stimulates the cochlear nerve directly through an electrode placed in the cochlea: Incorrect. This describes a cochlear implant, not an ABI. ABI is used when the cochlear nerve is non-functional or absent, such as after surgical severance during vestibular schwannoma removal.

 

Option B. ABI is indicated in patients with unilateral vestibular schwannoma and normal hearing on the opposite side: Incorrect. In unilateral cases, the contralateral hearing is sufficient, and ABI is not required. ABI is indicated in bilateral acoustic neuromas, such as in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).

 

Option D. ABI provides better speech recognition outcomes than multichannel cochlear implants: Incorrect. While ABIs improve awareness of environmental sounds and aid communication, their speech recognition outcomes are inferior to those of multichannel cochlear implants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory Brainstem Implants (ABIs) are placed in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle to stimulate the cochlear nucleus complex when the cochlear nerve is absent or non-functional.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 127

choices.text: Mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with good benefit from hearing aids
Bilateral conductive hearing loss with intact cognitive function
Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with little or no benefit from hearing aids
Severe hearing loss in one ear with normal hearing in the other

questions.text: Which of the following is an essential candidacy criterion for cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with little or no benefit from hearing aids

 

  • This is the primary indication for cochlear implants. Additional criteria include no surgical contraindication, realistic expectations, cognitive ability, and strong family/social support.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with good benefit from hearing aids: Incorrect. Cochlear implantation is not indicated if the patient derives sufficient benefit from conventional hearing aids and does not have severe or profound loss.

 

Option B. Bilateral conductive hearing loss with intact cognitive function: Incorrect. Conductive hearing loss is typically managed by surgery or hearing aids. Cochlear implants are reserved for sensorineural deafness, especially when hearing aids fail.

 

Option D. Severe hearing loss in one ear with normal hearing in the other: Incorrect. This describes single-sided deafness, which may be managed with CROS aids or BAHA, not typically with cochlear implants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochlear implants are indicated in patients with bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss who derive minimal or no benefit from hearing aids.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

choices.text: BAHA transmits sound through the external auditory canal and ossicular chain
BAHA is contraindicated in conductive or mixed hearing loss
The sound processor of BAHA is implanted at the time of initial surgery
BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bone-Anchored Hearing Aids (BAHA) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear

 

  • BAHA uses a titanium fixture surgically implanted into the skull. Once osseointegrated, a sound processor attached to the external abutment sends vibrations through the skull directly to the cochlea, effectively bypassing the external and middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BAHA transmits sound through the external auditory canal and ossicular chain: Incorrect. Unlike conventional air-conduction aids, BAHA bypasses both the external auditory canal and the ossicular chain, delivering vibrations directly to the cochlea through bone conduction.

 

Option B. BAHA is contraindicated in conductive or mixed hearing loss: Incorrect. BAHA is primarily indicated for conductive, mixed, and single-sided deafness, especially in patients who cannot use traditional hearing aids.

 

Option C. The sound processor of BAHA is implanted at the time of initial surgery
Incorrect. The sound processor is attached only after osseointegration of the titanium implant, which typically takes 2–6 months after surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone conduction, bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

choices.text: Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means
Sensorineural hearing loss is a contraindication for hearing aids due to inevitable sound distortion
Conductive hearing loss is not treated with hearing aids under any circumstance
Hearing aids are delayed in deaf children until after 5 years of age to assess speech development

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the indications for hearing aid use is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means

 

  • This is the fundamental indication for hearing aids — to amplify sound in patients with hearing impairment not amenable to medical or surgical treatment, including many with sensorineural or conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss is a contraindication for hearing aids due to inevitable sound distortion: Incorrect. While some patients with sensorineural loss may experience sound distortion or recruitment, many can benefit from hearing aids if properly fitted.

 

Option C. Conductive hearing loss is not treated with hearing aids under any circumstance: Incorrect. While surgery is preferred, hearing aids are prescribed when surgery is refused, not feasible, or has failed.

 

Option D. Hearing aids are delayed in deaf children until after 5 years of age to assess speech development: Incorrect. Early fitting of hearing aids is essential in deaf children to promote speech and language development, ideally as early as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hearing aids are indicated for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical treatment.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

choices.text: Blepharospasm usually affects only one eye and is most commonly caused by acoustic neuroma
Botulinum toxin is ineffective in hemifacial spasm but useful in treating exposure keratitis
Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle
Selective nerve section is contraindicated in the treatment of essential hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding hyperkinetic disorders of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle

 

  • Many cases of hemifacial spasm are due to neurovascular compression at the cerebellopontine angle, often by a vascular loop. Treatment includes microvascular decompression, which has a high success rate.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Blepharospasm usually affects only one eye and is most commonly caused by acoustic neuroma: Incorrect. Blepharospasm is a bilateral involuntary spasm of orbicularis oculi muscles and is not typically caused by acoustic neuroma. Its origin is believed to lie in the basal ganglia.

 

Option B. Botulinum toxin is ineffective in hemifacial spasm but useful in treating exposure keratitis: Incorrect. Botulinum toxin is effective in both hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm. It works by blocking acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction. It is not used for exposure keratitis.

 

Option D. Selective nerve section is contraindicated in the treatment of essential hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm: Incorrect. Selective section of facial nerve branches may be considered in essential hemifacial spasm or blepharospasm if other treatments fail. It is not contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemifacial spasm may be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle and is treatable by microvascular decompression or botulinum toxin.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103–104.

choices.text: Most commonly caused by parietal blows and associated with conductive hearing loss
Often associated with bleeding from the ear and injury to ossicles
Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases
Characterized by CSF otorrhea that is usually mixed with blood

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding transverse fractures of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases

 

  • Transverse fractures are less common (20%) and usually result from occipital blows. They run across the petrous part of the temporal bone and often damage the labyrinth or CN VIII, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. They also frequently cause immediate facial paralysis (50%), due to injury in the meatal or labyrinthine segment proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

 

 

(A) Longitudinal fracture follows the long axis of the petrous part of the temporal bone. It typically originates from the squamous part of the temporal bone, extends through the roof of the external auditory canal and middle ear, and continues toward the petrous apex, ending near the foramen lacerum.

 

(B) Transverse fracture runs perpendicular to the petrous axis. It usually begins at the foramen magnum, traverses the occipital bone and jugular fossa, passes through the petrous pyramid, and ends in the middle cranial fossa. In its course, it may pass medial to, lateral to, or directly through the labyrinth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most commonly caused by parietal blows and associated with conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. This describes longitudinal fractures, which are more common (80%), result from parietal blows, and cause conductive hearing loss.

 

Option B. Often associated with bleeding from the ear and injury to ossicles: Incorrect. Again, this is seen in longitudinal fractures, due to involvement of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

 

Option D. Characterized by CSF otorrhea that is usually mixed with blood: Incorrect. CSF otorrhea mixed with blood is more typical of longitudinal fractures, not transverse ones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse temporal bone fractures typically cause sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis due to injury to the labyrinth or proximal facial nerve.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100–101.

choices.text: Objective tinnitus is most commonly psychogenic and occurs without any identifiable physical source
Venous hum and vascular lesions like glomus tumors are typical causes of subjective tinnitus
Clicking tinnitus due to palatal myoclonus is an example of subjective tinnitus that occurs during swallowing
Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

questions.text: Which of the following statements about causes of tinnitus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

 

  • These conditions cause objective tinnitus. A patulous (patent) eustachian tube causes respiration-synchronous tinnitus, while palatal myoclonus produces a clicking sound due to rhythmic contractions of the soft palate.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Objective tinnitus is most commonly psychogenic and occurs without any identifiable physical source: Incorrect. Psychogenic tinnitus is a form of subjective tinnitus, and objective tinnitus typically has a real, physical cause such as vascular or muscular abnormalities.

 

Option B. Venous hum and vascular lesions like glomus tumors are typical causes of subjective tinnitus: Incorrect. These are classic causes of objective tinnitus, often synchronous with the pulse, and may be temporarily relieved by pressure on vessels.

 

Option C. Clicking tinnitus due to palatal myoclonus is an example of subjective tinnitus that occurs during swallowing: Incorrect. Palatal myoclonus is a cause of objective tinnitus, as the sound is produced by actual muscular contractions and can sometimes be heard by an examiner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tinnitus may result from physical sources like palatal myoclonus or a patulous eustachian tube, producing sounds synchronized with muscle activity or respiration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

choices.text: Recurrent facial paralysis, ear discharge, and conductive hearing loss
Recurrent facial paralysis, lip swelling, and fissured tongue
Bilateral facial paralysis, ocular pain, and nasal crusting
Sudden facial paralysis, mastoid tenderness, and vertigo

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is characteristic of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent facial paralysis, lip swelling, and fissured tongue

 

  • This classic triad defines Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome. The facial paralysis may be recurrent, and treatment is similar to Bell palsy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Recurrent facial paralysis, ear discharge, and conductive hearing loss
Incorrect. These features are more suggestive of chronic otitis media, not Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

 

Option C. Bilateral facial paralysis, ocular pain, and nasal crusting: Incorrect. While bilateral facial paralysis can occur in systemic conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome and sarcoidosis, the other symptoms listed do not characterize Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

 

Option D. Sudden facial paralysis, mastoid tenderness, and vertigo: Incorrect. These features suggest acute mastoiditis with possible labyrinthitis, not Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is defined by a triad of recurrent facial paralysis, swelling of the lips, and a fissured tongue.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100.

choices.text: Hypoglossal-facial anastomosis restores facial movement without any impact on tongue function
End-to-end anastomosis is preferred when the nerve gap is large and requires tension to bridge
Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis
Decompression involves rerouting the entire facial nerve to relieve mechanical pressure

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding surgical management of facial nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis

 

  • In cases where the gap is too wide for safe end-to-end approximation, nerve grafts (such as from greater auricular, sural, or lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh) are used to bridge the defect.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Hypoglossal-facial anastomosis restores facial movement without any impact on tongue function: Incorrect. While this procedure improves facial tone and some movement, it does lead to ipsilateral tongue atrophy, causing temporary difficulties in chewing and articulation.

 

Option B. End-to-end anastomosis is preferred when the nerve gap is large and requires tension to bridge: Incorrect. End-to-end anastomosis is only done when the gap is minimal, and no tension is present between the ends. Tension can compromise healing and function.

 

Option D. Decompression involves rerouting the entire facial nerve to relieve mechanical pressure: Incorrect. Decompression involves uncapping the bony canal and slitting the nerve sheath to relieve pressure from edema or hematoma. It does not involve rerouting the nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cable grafting is indicated when the gap between severed facial nerve ends is too large to allow tension-free end-to-end anastomosis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 105.

choices.text: They amplify sound in the external canal and transmit it acoustically to the tympanic membrane
Piezoelectric devices work by generating a magnetic field around the ossicles
Electromagnetic devices use crystal expansion to directly stimulate the cochlea
They work by delivering mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes implantable middle ear hearing aids?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) They work by delivering mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal

 

  • Implantable middle ear hearing aids use direct-drive technology to mechanically stimulate the ossicles, thus bypassing the external canal and tympanic membrane. This keeps the ear canal open and may benefit users sensitive to occlusion effects.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. They amplify sound in the external canal and transmit it acoustically to the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. This describes traditional air-conduction hearing aids, not implantable hearing devices. Implantable devices bypass the ear canal entirely.

 

Option B. Piezoelectric devices work by generating a magnetic field around the ossicles: Incorrect. Piezoelectric devices work by applying electric current to a piezoceramic crystal, which changes shape and creates mechanical vibrations — not magnetic fields.

 

Option C. Electromagnetic devices use crystal expansion to directly stimulate the cochlea: Incorrect. This describes piezoelectric devices. Electromagnetic devices function by inducing a magnetic field that vibrates a magnet attached to an ossicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Implantable middle ear hearing aids deliver mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123

choices.text: Cochlear implants deliver amplified sound signals directly to the hair cells in the cochlea
The external component includes the receiver and electrode array, both surgically implanted behind the ear
Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve via electrical impulses transmitted through an electrode array placed in the scala tympani
The speech processor in a cochlear implant is always body-worn and cannot be placed behind the ear

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve via electrical impulses transmitted through an electrode array placed in the scala tympani

 

  • The electrode array, placed in the scala tympani, stimulates the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve using electrical impulses processed by the external speech processor and internal receiver/stimulator.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cochlear implants deliver amplified sound signals directly to the hair cells in the cochlea: Incorrect. Cochlear implants bypass the damaged hair cells entirely. They deliver electrical impulses directly to the auditory nerve via an electrode array.

 

Option B. The external component includes the receiver and electrode array, both surgically implanted behind the ear: Incorrect. The receiver and electrode array are part of the internal component, which is surgically implanted. The external component includes the speech processor and transmitter.

 

Option D. The speech processor in a cochlear implant is always body-worn and cannot be placed behind the ear: Incorrect. Modern cochlear implants often use behind-the-ear (BTE) speech processors, which are now preferred over body-worn devices for cosmetic and functional reasons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve through electrical impulses delivered by an electrode array placed in the scala tympani.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

choices.text: Routine use of tympanoplasty to improve candidacy
Cochlear implantation can proceed without imaging if audiometry is conclusive
Vaccination against hepatitis B is mandatory before implantation
Audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological evaluations are required to assess suitability and predict outcomes

questions.text: Which of the following is an essential part of preoperative evaluation for cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological evaluations are required to assess suitability and predict outcomes

 

  • A comprehensive evaluation including:
    • Medical fitness and vaccination
    • Audiological testing (e.g., PTA, ABR, OAE, ASSR)
    • Imaging (CT/MRI)
    • Speech-language assessment
    • Hearing aid trial
    • Psychological assessment
      helps in confirming candidacy and counseling the patient/family about realistic expectations.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Routine use of tympanoplasty to improve candidacy: Incorrect. Tympanoplasty is not a routine or required part of cochlear implant evaluation. Cochlear implants bypass the middle ear and tympanic membrane entirely.

 

Option B. Cochlear implantation can proceed without imaging if audiometry is conclusive: Incorrect. Imaging (CT and MRI) of the cochlea, auditory nerve, and brain is essential to assess cochlear anatomy and rule out anomalies that may complicate surgery.

 

Option C. Vaccination against hepatitis B is mandatory before implantation: Incorrect. Vaccination against meningitis (especially H. influenzae type B, Pneumococcus, and Meningococcus) is mandatory due to increased risk after cochlear implantation—not hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochlear implant candidacy requires thorough evaluation including audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological assessments.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 126

choices.text: Spectacle hearing aids are the most commonly used type due to their multifunctionality
Bone conduction hearing aids are ideal for patients with intact ear canals and no external ear pathology
In-the-ear (ITE) hearing aids are mainly used in children with congenital deafness
Body-worn hearing aids allow high amplification with minimal feedback and are useful in children with congenital deafness

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding types of hearing aids is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Body-worn hearing aids allow high amplification with minimal feedback and are useful in children with congenital deafness

 

  • Body-worn aids have the microphone, amplifier, and battery in a chest-level unit, with the receiver at the ear. They allow high amplification with low feedback, making them suitable for severe hearing loss and for children with congenital deafness.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Spectacle hearing aids are the most commonly used type due to their multifunctionality: Incorrect. Although they combine hearing and vision support, spectacle hearing aids are not popular today and are rarely used.

 

Option B. Bone conduction hearing aids are ideal for patients with intact ear canals and no external ear pathology: Incorrect. Bone conduction aids are specifically indicated for patients with draining ears, atresia of the ear canal, or otitis externa — i.e., those who cannot use ear inserts.

 

Option C. In-the-ear (ITE) hearing aids are mainly used in children with congenital deafness: Incorrect. ITE aids are usually used in adults with mild to moderate hearing loss. Body-worn aids are more suited to children with congenital deafness due to better amplification and control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Body-worn hearing aids offer strong amplification with minimal feedback and are especially beneficial for children with congenital deafness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

choices.text: The internal component contains a microphone and amplifier that transmit sound to the tympanic membrane
The external component is surgically implanted into the mastoid bone
The Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) is connected to the tympanic membrane and stimulates it directly
The internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) connected to the incus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Vibrant Soundbridge device is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) connected to the incus

 

  • The internal part, known as the Vibrating Ossicular Prosthesis (VORP), consists of a receiver, a Floating Mass Transducer, and a connecting link. The FMT is attached to the incus to transmit mechanical vibrations to the inner ear.

 

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The internal component contains a microphone and amplifier that transmit sound to the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. The microphone is part of the external audio processor, not the internal component. Also, the device transmits sound to the ossicles, not to the tympanic membrane.

 

Option B. The external component is surgically implanted into the mastoid bone: Incorrect. The external audio processor is worn behind the ear, not implanted. It communicates with the internal receiver via radiofrequency waves.

 

Option C. The Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) is connected to the tympanic membrane and stimulates it directly: Incorrect. The FMT is connected to the incus, not the tympanic membrane, and delivers mechanical vibrations to the ossicular chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vibrant Soundbridge's internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) that is connected to the incus to deliver mechanical sound stimulation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123

choices.text: The facial nerve lies lateral to the short process of incus at the level of aditus
The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus
The tympanic segment of the facial nerve starts at the posterior end of the digastric ridge
The geniculate ganglion is located posterior to the processus cochleariformis

questions.text: During middle ear surgery, which of the following correctly describes a key surgical landmark for identifying the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

 

  • The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus. This is a key landmark for the mastoid or vertical segment of the facial nerve during surgery.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The facial nerve lies lateral to the short process of incus at the level of aditus: Incorrect. The facial nerve lies medial to the short process of incus, not lateral, at the level of the aditus ad antrum.

 

Option C. The tympanic segment of the facial nerve starts at the posterior end of the digastric ridge: Incorrect. The tympanic segment begins at the level of the processus cochleariformis, not near the digastric ridge. The digastric ridge is related to the exit point of the nerve from the mastoid.

 

Option D. The geniculate ganglion is located posterior to the processus cochleariformis: Incorrect. The geniculate ganglion lies anterior to the processus cochleariformis and is the site where the nerve takes its first turn (first genu).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus in its vertical (mastoid) segment, serving as a key landmark in middle ear surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.

choices.text: It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus
It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen
It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis
It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

 

  • The labyrinthine segment is just 4 mm long and has the narrowest bony canal (0.61–0.68 mm), making it the most vulnerable segment to inflammation or edema, which can cause facial nerve paralysis.

 

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus: Incorrect. The meatal segment lies within the internal acoustic meatus and measures 8–10 mm, but the labyrinthine segment is shorter (about 4 mm).

 

Option B. It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen
Incorrect. This describes the combined tympanic and mastoid segments, not the labyrinthine segment.

 

Option D. It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal
Incorrect. This describes the tympanic (horizontal) segment, not the labyrinthine segment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is the shortest and narrowest portion, making it highly susceptible to compression-induced facial paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90

choices.text: CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear
CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss
CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity
CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signals) hearing aids is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

 

  • CROS hearing aids are used in single-sided deafness, where they route sound from the non-hearing side to the hearing side, improving awareness and localization. However, bone-anchored hearing aids are now preferred alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear: Incorrect. This describes bone conduction hearing aids or bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA), not CROS. CROS aids use a microphone on the deaf side and receiver on the normal side.

 

Option B. CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. CROS aids are specifically designed for unilateral profound hearing loss, not bilateral.

 

Option C. CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity: Incorrect. It is the reverse — CROS aids pick up sound from the deaf ear side and send it to the better ear to help with sound localization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CROS hearing aids route sound from the deaf ear to the better ear, helping with sound localization in cases of single-sided deafness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

choices.text: The electrode array is placed in the scala vestibuli to directly stimulate the organ of Corti
The receiver/stimulator is placed externally and anchored over the skin above the mastoid bone
The facial recess approach involves cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window niche
The suprameatal recess approach requires a wide mastoid cavity and stapedectomy for electrode insertion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding cochlear implant surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The facial recess approach involves cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window niche

 

  • This is a standard surgical approach in cochlear implantation. It allows safe access to the round window by opening the facial recess, which lies between the facial nerve and chorda tympani.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The electrode array is placed in the scala vestibuli to directly stimulate the organ of Corti: Incorrect. The electrode array is inserted into the scala tympani, not the scala vestibuli. This places it close to the spiral ganglion cells for optimal stimulation.

 

Option B. The receiver/stimulator is placed externally and anchored over the skin above the mastoid bone: Incorrect. The receiver/stimulator is implanted surgically in a bony well drilled into the skull and covered by skin flaps. It is not placed externally.

 

Option D. The suprameatal recess approach requires a wide mastoid cavity and stapedectomy for electrode insertion: Incorrect. The suprameatal recess (Veria) approach is a pericanal technique that does not require stapedectomy or a wide mastoid cavity. It uses a tunnel drilled along the external canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochlear implant surgery commonly uses the facial recess approach, involving cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window for electrode insertion.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 126

choices.text: Cervical spondylosis involving C2 and C3 nerve roots
Impacted third molar causing temporomandibular joint pain
Malignant ulcer of the tonsil or soft palate
Ulcerative lesion of the larynx involving the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is a referred cause of earache transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malignant ulcer of the tonsil or soft palate

 

  • These structures are innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX). Pain from lesions here can be referred to the ear, as the tympanic branch of IX also supplies the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cervical spondylosis involving C2 and C3 nerve roots: Incorrect. This refers to referred pain via cervical spinal nerves (C2, C3) — not via the IX cranial nerve.

 

Option B. Impacted third molar causing temporomandibular joint pain: Incorrect. Dental issues and TMJ disorders refer pain via the auriculotemporal branch of the trigeminal nerve (V).

 

Option D. Ulcerative lesion of the larynx involving the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. This refers to a referred cause via the vagus nerve (X cranial nerve), not IX.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant or ulcerative lesions of the tonsil or soft palate refer pain to the ear via the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg.128

choices.text: Tinnitus is a disease of the auditory nerve and always requires surgical treatment
Hearing aids are only used to amplify sound and have no role in managing tinnitus
Tinnitus maskers may provide temporary relief due to the phenomenon of residual inhibition
Sedatives are avoided in all tinnitus cases due to risk of worsening symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of tinnitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tinnitus maskers may provide temporary relief due to the phenomenon of residual inhibition

 

  • Tinnitus maskers, worn like hearing aids, emit low-level noise to mask the perception of tinnitus. In some individuals, even after turning them off, a residual inhibition effect persists, offering temporary relief from symptoms.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tinnitus is a disease of the auditory nerve and always requires surgical treatment: Incorrect. Tinnitus is a symptom, not a standalone disease. It may originate from various auditory or systemic causes, and surgery is rarely indicated.

 

Option B. Hearing aids are only used to amplify sound and have no role in managing tinnitus: Incorrect. Hearing aids help mask tinnitus in patients with hearing loss and can significantly improve quality of life.

 

Option D. Sedatives are avoided in all tinnitus cases due to risk of worsening symptoms: Incorrect. Sedatives and tranquilizers may be used, especially in the early stages, to help patients adjust to the symptom, particularly if there is significant anxiety or sleep disturbance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinnitus maskers can provide symptom relief through residual inhibition, especially in patients without hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

choices.text: TRT aims to completely mask tinnitus sounds using high-volume white noise
TRT is based on the principle that tinnitus itself causes distress, not emotional reactions
TRT involves habituation of both emotional reaction and conscious perception of tinnitus
TRT is a short-term therapy lasting 2–3 weeks and does not require counseling

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TRT involves habituation of both emotional reaction and conscious perception of tinnitus

 

  • TRT works at two levels:
    • Habituation of reaction – uncoupling emotional response from tinnitus.
    • Habituation of perception – reducing awareness of tinnitus.
      It combines counseling and sound therapy over 18–24 months to help patients stop reacting to tinnitus.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. TRT aims to completely mask tinnitus sounds using high-volume white noise: Incorrect. TRT does not aim to mask the tinnitus but to habituate the patient to it using low-level, continuous sound exposure. Masking is not the therapeutic goal.

 

Option B. TRT is based on the principle that tinnitus itself causes distress, not emotional reactions: Incorrect. TRT is founded on the concept that it is not tinnitus itself, but the emotional and autonomic response (via limbic and autonomic systems) that causes distress.

 

Option D. TRT is a short-term therapy lasting 2–3 weeks and does not require counseling: Incorrect. TRT is a long-term therapy (18–24 months) and counseling is a critical component alongside sound therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT) involves habituation of both emotional response and conscious perception of tinnitus using counseling and sound therapy over a long duration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 131

choices.text: Frey’s syndrome due to misdirection of fibers to the auriculotemporal nerve
Crocodile tears syndrome due to misdirected parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland
Palatal myoclonus with associated lacrimal hyperactivity
Glossopharyngeal neuralgia with referred lacrimation

questions.text: A patient develops unilateral tearing while eating, several months after recovery from facial nerve injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crocodile tears syndrome due to misdirected parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland

 

  • Also called gustatory lacrimation, this condition occurs when parasympathetic fibers intended for salivary glands regenerate incorrectly and supply the lacrimal gland, leading to unilateral tearing while eating. Treatment includes sectioning the greater superficial petrosal nerve or tympanic neurectomy.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Frey’s syndrome due to misdirection of fibers to the auriculotemporal nerve: Incorrect. Frey’s syndrome presents with gustatory sweating over the parotid region, not lacrimation. It is due to misdirected parasympathetic fibers from the auriculotemporal nerve after parotid trauma/surgery.

 

Option C. Palatal myoclonus with associated lacrimal hyperactivity: Incorrect. Palatal myoclonus causes objective clicking tinnitus, not lacrimation, and is unrelated to eating or salivary pathways.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal neuralgia with referred lacrimation: Incorrect. Glossopharyngeal neuralgia causes episodic throat and ear pain, not lacrimation during eating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crocodile tears syndrome is caused by misdirected parasympathetic fibers after facial nerve trauma, leading to unilateral lacrimation while eating.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 23, 110, 113, 251
